page.title: 19NATURAL HISTORY OF THE AREA
page.content: THERE IS A NICE ECOLOGICAL BALANCE IN THIS REGION, WITH MANY NATURAL HABITATS SUPPORTING A WIDE RANGE OF FLORA AND FAUNA. POPULAR WILD PLANTS INCLUDE THE STINGING NETTLE, BRAMBLE, ELDER FLOWER (AND BERRIES) AND WILD ROSES. MANY OF THESE ARE USED BY THE COUNTRY PEOPLE TO MAKE PRESERVES AND DELICIOUS WINES. ELDERFLOWER CHAMPAGNE IS A PARTICULAR FAVOURITE IN MANY HOUSEHOLDS AND IS VERY SIMPLE TO MAKE FROM A FEW FLOWER HEADS, SUGAR, YEAST AND WATER. LOCAL WILDLIFE INCLUDES MANY SPECIES OF BIRDS AND PIGEONS, MICE, RATS, HEDGEHOGS, MOLES, VOLES, RABBITS, FOXES AND SQUIRRELS. THE BANKS OF THE RESERVOIR HOUSE MANY RARE DUCKS WHICH THRIVE BECAUSE OF THE LACK OF POLLUTION. FOOTPATHS ABOUND WITHIN THIS AREA AROUND SPINNEYS AND SMALL WOODS, ALSO THE RESERVOIR. CLIMATE IS VERY PLEASANT, WITH FEW EXTREMES.
